Notes: Many species form ectomycorrhizal associations, often occupying a dominant position in mycorrhizal communities. Other species are pathogens of many different plants and even lichens, and one species has even been suggested to form a lichen association with cyanobacteria. Yet more species are sparse and active decomposers, and a few are aquatic (Cannon & Kirk 2007)
Citation/Source: Cannon PF, Kirk PM. 2007. Fungal Families of the World. CAB International, Cambridge

Notes: Most if not all of the species in this genus appear to be saprotrophic, although at one point some species were thought to be ectomycorrhizal. The history can be traced back: Rinaldi et al. (2008) cited Agerer (2006), who cited Ingleby et al. (1990), a report that had been based upon a description of ECM formed by Tricharina gilva. The report of Ingleby et al. (1990) was actually based upon a misidentification, as Egger (1996) sequenced dried ascocarp material obtained from Kevin Ingleby and found it to be Wilcoxina mikolae, which is known to form E-strain ECM.
Citation/Source: Egger KN. 1996. Canadian Journal of Botany 74:773-779; Rinaldi AC, Comandini O, Kuyper TW. 2008. Fungal Diversity 33:1-45 (ECM); Tedersoo L, May TW, Smith ME. 2010. Mycorrhiza 20:217-263 (pro parte); http://mycorrhizas.info/ecmf.html (ECM)
